author: Mr_JerryS
body:
$GOEV

1. Undervalued when compared to other EV plays, despite having nearly double the employees and over 3 times as many vehicles set to go into production in the next 3 years.




2. They've only been around since 2018. In that time, they've locked up a manufacturing agreement with magna, secured deal with Hyundai to produce vehicles using their chassis architecture, brought a vehicle from idea to production in just 19 months (average time 4-5 years), and even received a buyout bid from Apple... and had the balls to say no. Lucid, for example has been around since 2006 and has 1 vehicle going into production.




3. The multi-purpose delivery vehicle can reach distances up to 250 mi and will be sold at a starting point of $33,000. The workhorse vehicle for comparison can reach 100 mi and sells at $52,000. It does however have 200 cubic feet more space, but over 400 ft of exterior space making it more difficult to maneuver in a city. The engineering behind Canoos vehicles is simply much better.




4. Their skateboard chassis and their steer by wire technology make up 70% of the vehicle. This means that the cost of production is drastically lower since research and development, testing, and production are already complete on any future vehicle. this will allow them to bring new vehicles into production much quicker than their competitors. This point is validated by their partnership with Hyundai.




5. Don't underestimate the news that Apple sought a takeover bid. Apple could have targeted any EV company in the world, and they chose to go after Canoo. It is the only vehicle truly designed to be ridden in rather than driven. The engineers were clear that they were designing a vehicle to be eventually be fully autonomous.

author: nevetando
body:
Are there some tech stocks that are overvalued? yes. 

is all of tech overvalued? no.

But the whole sector is suffering because of a few. Just take a deep breath and relax. if you own any solid, diversified, mainstay tech (apple, Microsoft, even intel and AMD) you are going to be fine in the long run. 

If you are in emerging tech, new companies, growing companies... well, godspeed. it is going to be bumpy. 

History favors tech though. but like all things, it goes in and out of favor with the people.

author: shroomenheimer
body: "GME has ruined /r/wallstreetbets" he typed furiously. In his rage he had broken into a sweat and the wet meaty slap of his fingers against the mechanical keyboard echoed throughout his mother's basement. Fondly he reminisced of the first time he saw a "guh" commented in another subreddit. The joy of typing "/r/wallstreetbets is leaking" had brought him to near orgasm. Defeated, he typed in /r/investing, desperately looking for someone that cared about his AAPL calls.

author: je_veux_sentir
body:
Insanely undervalued now. 

Apple is a solid company with probably the best balance sheets you’ll find. It’s hard to go wrong if you are in it for the long term. 

That being said. Don’t expect to double your money each year. Apple will do well, and probably will beat the market, but it isnt going to double each year.

author: YOLOQuant
body:
On speculative tech stocks which promise positive cash flows far into the future. The frothier stocks might go even lower. TSLA for example has already had a 25% drop and I think more is on the table. Growth stocks with solid cash flows (AAPL) likely bottoms out around 10-15%. Value stocks will continue to edge higher.

My base case for the S+P is around 10-15% from ATH.

author: shintaro_the_doggo
body:
When I was in middle school, my friend and I were in an extracurricular activity where we played a virtual "stock market" game over the course of the year with 100,00 virtual dollars, competing with kids across the state. We were supposed to take the class time (something like an hour after school each week) to research stocks, invest in companies that seemed promising, etc.

My buddy and I YOLO'd the entire 100k into Apple so we could just fuck around and play video games on the internet instead of actually doing research and working. At the end of the competition period we had made more money than any other kids in the state, came in 1st in the competition, and went to the capitol to get an award.

author: rs6866
body:
Here's a great example: TSLA.

I think tsla is a great company and is going to grow and gain market share.  It has a reasonable chance of entirely dominating the EV space for years to come.

PE > 1000.  Yeah, but no.  Other mega cap tech names like MSFT or AAPL are around 30.  AMZN is 75.  TSLA needs to fall ~97% to achieve fair value.  Even if they grow 10x in the next 2-3 years (doubtful they can get there), they'd need to fall 30%.  Stay the hell away.

author: GoddardsPlumber
body:
Bro take a deep breath and crack a beer or go on a walk or something. I'm blown away at the amount of people on this sub who have gotten themselves in so deep that they can't even believe in a complex world full of unrelated chaos anymore. When someone gets run over texting on a Pixel in a crosswalk do you think it's AAPL trying to spread FUD to drop GOOGL prices? This shit is way bigger than some scary looking bald dude in an underwater cave pulling levers to raise and drop all stocks in unison. 

That having been said, holding my 60 GME @ $118.02 till I can retire on them...just not going to get too Heaven's Gate with them. 🍻🚀

author: Whole-Ad-7659
body:
I have a mix of options, warrants and commons. Pretty much all of my long term holds are in tech. Probably my biggest problem is timing. Right around the time chamath da with sofi I decided I wanted more spacs so I used pretty much all my reserves to buy more spacs. Then after the first big drop I saw it as an “opportunity” so I sold some commons in exchange for warrants. Well pretty much all those warrants are down 30%-60% since I bought them on the “dip”. 

And that is how you lose a years worth of gains in 2 weeks. And that’s really saying something because my portfolio has been propped up big time from Tesla, nio, apple and arkk over the last year. Live and learn I guess
